Award.AwardTitle: SG: Understanding local controls on wood decomposition in a regional context
Award.AbstractNarration:
A critical determinant of the carbon balance of forests is the rate at which dead wood decays. This is determined by the rate at which dead wood is formed and the rate at which it breaks down, or decomposes. Dead wood is also a hotspot for other nutrients to accumulate and it is a home for many species of animals, plants and microbes. Because trees contain a lot of carbon, our understanding of how the carbon cycle might be changing requires a better understanding of the wood decomposition process. With that in mind, this project will decompose logs from five common US tree species across a gradient spanning northeastern to southeastern US temperate forests. Potential controls on wood decomposition rates will be manipulated experimentally, such as the density of dead wood and the types of wood-decomposing fungi growing on the logs. Other factors, such as soil nutrient content, temperature and moisture will be monitored. The tree logs will be collected after a year of decay in the field and brought into the laboratory to assess their decomposition extent and associated wood-decaying fungi. The data will then be analyzed to determine wood decomposition rates under the different conditions. Information from this project will be used to refine predictions of carbon-cycle changes and the effects of environmental change on forests. The results will also provide guidance to the forest industry on management of dead wood stocks in forest.The importance of natural wood decay will be communicated through a collaborative effort with the Peabody Museum of Natural History, by creating "living" dead wood exhibits for public display and use in educating visiting middle-school students. The project will also train both graduate and undergraduate students in research, and will work with high-school summer interns from groups of students that are underrepresented in science.

Understanding the processes governing the decomposition of dead wood is essential for forest management, especially to mitigate negative effects of declining dead wood stocks on forest productivity, biodiversity and carbon storage. Controls on decomposition of leaf litter are better resolved, with climate and litter quality considered predominant regulators of decomposition rates at global and regional scales. These factors also regulate decomposition of dead wood, but additional unidentified controls mean that wood decomposition rates at regional scales are hard to predict with reasonable certainty. The objective of this work is to identify important, additional controls, which can then be used to formulate and parameterize carbon cycle models, where wood decomposition is a critical uncertainty. In single site studies, the primary factor affecting wood decomposition rates appears to be fungal community structure. Indeed, the species, strain and interactions of wood-rot fungi are strong determinants of decay rates. In particular, those fungi that aggregate their hyphae into thick mycelial cords are considered dominant agents of decomposition. These hyphal-aggregating fungi are termed non-unit-restricted fungi because their mycelia proliferate and interconnect discrete pieces of wood. The connectivity confers a strong competitive advantage, allowing fungi to rapidly colonize dead wood by accessing a broad suite of nutrient sources. As such, the working hypothesis of our project is: The decomposition of downed dead wood proceeds rapidly when non-unit restricted wood-rot fungi can colonize efficiently. A primary control on colonization, and hence fungal-mediated decomposition rates, is the proximity and abundance of coarse woody material (CWM). The working hypothesis will be tested with observational transects and common-garden experiments across five sites spanning a regional climate gradient in eastern US temperate forests. Transect studies will assess the decomposition of logs of five tree species, across pronounced microclimate gradients, either next to or away from natural CWM. Four common gardens at each site will comprise zero, medium and high levels of CWM, crossed with replicates that use plastic edging to disrupt foraging by non-unit restricted fungi. Competing hypotheses to explain the observed patterns of decomposition will be evaluated using field and laboratory assays estimating abiotic factors and the functional abilities of the decomposer communities. The project will engage high school students through an internship program, where graduating students who have college offers to pursue STEM majors, and who are from backgrounds under-represented in higher education, will pursue a paid, summer research position. The goal is to help redress the low (10%) college matriculation rate of this group. The project will also involve training at the graduate and undergraduate levels. Lastly, public outreach to 6th graders will be developed in collaboration with the Peabody Museum of Natural History, to expand their educational toolkit for school-visit programs, and to promote public interest in fungi, CWM and decomposition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Standing dead trees, otherwise known as snags, provide critical nesting and foraging habitat for many types of forest-dwelling wildlife. Snag-dependent birds include species of woodpeckers, owls, nuthatches, chickadees and hawks. Snags also provide dens for many mammals. Snags are therefore considered an integral part of any comprehensive management plan for temperate-zone forests. When snags are eventually downed, the tree trunks and branches crisscrossing the forest floor retain high conservation value, providing habitat and refuge (e.g. from fire) for a huge range of animals and microorganisms, including salamanders, ants, and fungi. Furthermore, many trees and shrubs depend on dead wood as sites of germination and survival, so the availability of dead wood can determine future forest composition. Further, as dead trees decompose, nutrients are released that are needed for new tree growth. Not surprisingly, in most forests around the world the management of downed wood is an increasing priority.

From a carbon accounting perspective, dead wood is a large global store, estimated to comprise 73 petagrams of carbon, or more than ten-times the amount of fossil fuel carbon released to the atmosphere each year. To sustain this carbon stock and the associated conservation value of dead wood, we need to understand the rate at which dead wood decomposes (i.e. is broken down) so that we can ensure it is replenished at a similar rate. The overarching goal of our project was to evaluate what factors control the decomposition rate of dead wood. Uncertainty about whether climate or other factors best explain and predict wood decomposition rates at broad spatial scales stems from a paucity of studies evaluating variation in controls across large geographic scales. In this study, we prepared and placed more than 1,600 downed logs, of five tree species common to the eastern U.S., into forests spanning a climate gradient from the White Mountains of New Hampshire to the Georgia piedmont. In addition, at a subset of the sites we installed 180 untreated wooden fence posts to study what factors controlled the decomposition and fall rate of standing dead wood. 

The nine published papers to date provide strong evidence that considering local scale heterogeneity (i.e. within site) can change our fundamental understanding of how and which factors regulate decomposition rates. For example, we find local moisture conditions to be a dominant control on decomposition rates of leaf litter, the wooden posts and also the downed logs. The work then contributes to a growing awareness that coarse-level estimates of moisture availability are likely unrepresentative of the moisture conditions that decomposer fungi experience. Our work reveals that moisture varies markedly within a meter from subsoil to aboveground, and also across the surface soil, generating very high variation in decomposition rates given its influence on the activities of wood-rot fungi and also termites. Our work is important then for informing the development of the new generation of microbially-explicit soil biogeochemical models. Such models are embedded in Earth system models, used to project carbon cycle-climate feedbacks and hence the potential consequences and management of ongoing hum-caused climate change. Confidence in these models depends on accurate knowledge about the controls regulating the rate at which plant (including wood) biomass is decomposed into products such as CO2. Our results emphasize that aggregating data on moisture and associated variables such as fungal biomass, strongly alters the projections of biogeochemical models concerning how climate change influences decomposition rates. Our data suggest the need to collect data at local spatial scales if we are to rely on them to estimate changes in decomposition under changing climatic conditions.

In addition to the training of a graduate students, our project provided multiple opportunities to engage those earlier in the STEM pathway, by engaging with and supporting established programs/ initiatives focused on building inclusion and retention of underrepresented groups. It leveraged the New Haven Promise initiative of Yale to help redress socioeconomic-related educational inequities, providing a summer internship to help college retention of a STEM undergraduate student. We received a supplement award to engage a female STEM undergraduate in the summer, for which she could use those data collected for her senior thesis. We engaged four students (two undergraduate, two high school) to develop students in/ from the New Haven public school system in science communication. The students each spent 100 hours developing their knowledge of the project and then communicating it to the general public by developing teaching exhibit materials that have been on display from fall 2018 in the Peabody Natural History Museum. The cart exhibit was made locally relevant, in particular for visiting 4th to 7th grade students, by recreating what an individual might find if they turned over a downed log in the natural areas managed by the city, not more than a mile from the museum.
